items.title: City Names 17 Schools Slated to Close
items.abstract: New York City education officials released the first round of names of schools to be shut down, with more names coming on Tuesday.
keywords: High School of Graphic Communication Arts

items.title: No Deal on Teacher Evaluations; City Risks Losing $450 Million
items.abstract: The United Federation of Teachers and the Bloomberg administration blamed each other for talks breaking down even as a midnight deadline approached.

items.title: De Blasio, Announcing Mayoral Bid, Pledges to Help People City Hall Forgot
items.abstract: Bill de Blasio, the city’s public advocate, promised to focus on education as well as neighborhood and pocketbook issues that he said had not been addressed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

items.title: Why American Giant Re-Designed Its Web Site
items.abstract: The metrics indicate the company made the right call. (Plus, the company has sold out all of its product.)

items.title: Patent Producers Clustered in Only a Few Cities
items.abstract: A new study by the Brookings Institution shows the high concentration of patented innovation in a relatively small number of metropolitan areas in America. Twenty metro areas — home to 34 percent of the population — generate 63 percent of the nation’s patents.

items.title: New York City’s High School Graduation Rate Tops 70%
items.abstract: The announcement, which also noted that just over 78 percent of state students earned a diploma, came as state officials met to consider changes in graduation requirements.

items.title: As Cuomo Acts on Homeless Problem, New York City Blames State Cuts
items.abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is only one player in addressing the issue in the city, but decisions his administration has made have left the city shouldering more of the burden.

items.title: In Rural Alabama, a Longtime Mistrust of Medicine Fuels a Tuberculosis Outbreak
items.abstract: Marion, Ala., is in the throes of a tuberculosis outbreak so severe that it has posted an incidence rate that is about 100 times greater than the state’s and worse than many developing countries.

items.title: New York City to Get $176 Million From U.S. for Storm Protections
items.abstract: Senator Chuck Schumer said the city would be awarded federal funds for a proposed project to guard against another storm like Hurricane Sandy in Lower Manhattan.

items.title: Video Review: Chevy Volt Impresses With Tech, Design and Driving Pleasure
items.abstract: The second-generation Chevy Volt, a plug-in hybrid available this spring, is more efficient than its predecessor, looks better and is about $1,000 less expensive. It’s also fun to drive.
keywords: Chevrolet Division of General Motors Corp

items.title: Relief for New York City’s Transit Deserts? Commuter Trains Might Help
items.abstract: A planned billion-dollar rail expansion in the Bronx is fueling a larger debate over using aboveground trains to supplement subway and bus service.

items.title: Five Takeaways From Mayor Bill de Blasio’s State of the City Address
items.abstract: Sounding at times like a motivational speaker, the mayor vowed to keep working to improve New Yorkers’ lives while taking his message to a national audience.

items.title: Students in Rural America Ask, ‘What Is a University Without a History Major?’
items.abstract: Financial and enrollment woes at schools like the University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point have led to a scramble for fixes, such as dropping longstanding liberal arts degrees.

items.title: The Economic Squeeze on Rural Colleges
items.abstract: Readers see politics at work and a lost opportunity for middle and lower income students.

items.title: A Bolaño Novel About Young Poets in Mexico City, Hungry for Fame, Sex and Adventure. No, Not That One.
items.abstract: Roberto Bolaño’s coming-of-age tale “The Spirit of Science Fiction,” written around 1984, foreshadows the Chilean author’s epic 1998 breakthrough, “The Savage Detectives.”

items.title: Eric Adams Takes Office as New York City’s 110th Mayor at a Perilous Moment
items.abstract: Eric Adams, the city’s second Black mayor, faces difficult decisions over how to lead New York City through the next wave of the pandemic.

items.title: ‘Attempted Security Threat’ Disables Software at Some New York Schools
items.abstract: The outage in a platform used by teachers and students has caused another disruption for a system that has had its share amid the pandemic.
keywords: Goldstein, Leon M, High School for the Sciences (Brooklyn, NY)

items.title: A California City Is Overrun by Crows. Could a Laser Be the Answer?
items.abstract: In a move befitting its Silicon Valley setting, the city of Sunnyvale, Calif., will aim a laser at 1,000 birds that have overwhelmed the downtown area during the pandemic.
keywords: Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)

items.title: Is There Medical Neglect in New York City Jails?
items.abstract: A court filing says missed appointments lead to serious health consequences.

items.title: Boerum Hill, Brooklyn: A ‘Village in the City’
items.abstract: With its desirable 19th-century rowhouses and convenient subway access, the neighborhood is both homey and worldly.
